intro.title: Brainteract: A New Way to Explore the Brain and Nervous System
intro.description1: Brainteract is an interactive 3D platform designed to provide a deeper understanding of the brain and nervous system. Through realistic models and detailed explanations, it aims to make theoretical knowledge more accessible by visualizing complex structures. With Brainteract, you can explore brain lobes, neurons, and neural networks in detail, clicking on each region to access relevant scientific information.
intro.description2: This platform serves as a valuable resource for students, researchers, and anyone interested in neuroscience. By interacting with Brainteract, you can discover how the brain functions, understand how neurons communicate, and closely examine the structure of the nervous system. Our goal is to make neuroscience more accessible by offering an open environment for both learning and exploration.
intro.developer: Brainteract was developed by psychologist Fırat Altun.
intro.development: This project is still under development, so you may encounter some errors. Your feedback is valuable to us!

1.name: Amygdala
1.description: Processes emotions, particularly fear and anxiety. It's crucial for emotional learning and memory formation.

2.name: Hippocampus
2.description: Essential for learning and memory formation, especially long-term memory and spatial navigation.

3.name: Anterior Cingulate Cortex
3.description: Involved in emotion regulation, decision-making, impulse control, and error detection.

4.name: Hypothalamus
4.description: Regulates basic functions including hunger, thirst, body temperature, and circadian rhythms.

5.name: Pituitary Gland
5.description: The master endocrine gland that produces hormones affecting growth, metabolism, and stress response.

1.name: Corpus Callosum
1.description: A thick band of nerve fibers that connects the two hemispheres of the brain, allowing them to communicate.

2.name: Frontal Lobe
2.description: Responsible for executive functions, including planning, decision-making, problem-solving, and motor control.

3.name: Parietal Lobe
3.description: Processes sensory information and is involved in spatial awareness, navigation, and attention.

4.name: Temporal Lobe
4.description: Involved in processing auditory information, memory formation, and language comprehension.

5.name: Occipital Lobe
5.description: The visual processing center of the brain, responsible for interpreting visual information.

6.name: Central Sulcus
6.description: A major groove that separates the frontal and parietal lobes, dividing motor and sensory areas.

7.name: Lateral Sulcus
7.description: Also known as the Sylvian fissure, separates the temporal lobe from the frontal and parietal lobes.

8.name: Parieto-Occipital Sulcus
8.description: A groove that marks the boundary between the parietal and occipital lobes.

9.name: Callosal Sulcus
9.description: A groove that runs along the corpus callosum, separating it from the cingulate gyrus.

10.name: Cingulate Sulcus
10.description: A groove that runs along the cingulate gyrus, part of the limbic system.

1.name: Axon Terminal
1.description: The end of the axon where neurotransmitters are released to communicate with other neurons.

2.name: Node of Ranvier
2.description: Gaps in the myelin sheath that allow for saltatory conduction of nerve impulses.

3.name: Schwann Cell
3.description: Glial cells that produce the myelin sheath in the peripheral nervous system.

4.name: Myelin Sheath
4.description: A fatty insulating layer that speeds up nerve signal transmission along axons.

5.name: Axon
5.description: A long projection that conducts electrical impulses away from the neuron cell body.

6.name: Soma
6.description: The cell body of the neuron containing the nucleus and other vital organelles.

7.name: Dendrites
7.description: Branch-like extensions that receive signals from other neurons.

8.name: Nucleus
8.description: Contains the cell's genetic material and controls cellular activities.

1.name: Visual Field
1.description: The entire area that can be seen when the eyes are focused on a single point.

2.name: Retina
2.description: Light-sensitive layer at the back of the eye that converts light into neural signals.

3.name: Optic Nerve
3.description: Carries visual information from the retina to the brain.

4.name: Optic Chiasma
4.description: The point where the optic nerves partially cross, enabling integrated vision from both eyes.

5.name: Optic Tract
5.description: Neural pathway that carries visual information from the optic chiasm to the lateral geniculate nucleus.

6.name: Lateral Geniculate Nucleus
6.description: A relay center in the thalamus for visual information processing.

7.name: Optic Radiation
7.description: Neural fibers carrying visual information from the LGN to the visual cortex.

8.name: Occipital Lobe
8.description: Contains the primary visual cortex and processes visual information.

1.name: Anterior Cerebral Artery
1.description: Supplies blood to the frontal and medial parts of the cerebral hemispheres.

2.name: Middle Cerebral Artery
2.description: The largest cerebral artery, supplying blood to lateral areas of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes.

3.name: Posterior Cerebral Artery
3.description: Supplies blood to the occipital lobe and parts of the temporal lobe.

4.name: Circle of Willis
4.description: A circular arrangement of arteries that provides backup circulation to the brain.

5.name: Basilar Artery
5.description: Formed by the union of vertebral arteries, supplies blood to the brainstem and posterior brain.
